dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, all this inflation we're seeing, it's just because the Fed printed too much money, right? Pretty simple fix, I guess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, all this inflation we're seeing, it's just because the Fed printed too much money, right? Pretty simple fix, I guess.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, well, that's actually, um, a pretty common misconception, A. It's way, way more complicated than just that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, well, that's actually, um, a pretty common misconception, A. It's way, way more complicated than just that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To rein in surging price growth, the Federal Reserve and other central banks must adjust to the challenges of a rapidly deglobalizing world. Globalization acted as a deflationary force by reducing labor and production costs. Likewise, the main features of deglobalization higher tariffs and other trade barriers, together with a shift from global to regional trade flows are known drivers of inflation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh. Really? I thought that was, like, the main thing. So, what else is going on?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh. Really? I thought that was, like, the main thing. So, what else is going on?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: For starters, we're still dealing with, um, major supply-chain issues. China's zero-COVID and Russia's war, those are still really driving up food and fuel prices.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For starters, we're still dealing with, um, major supply-chain issues. China's zero-COVID and Russia's war, those are still really driving up food and fuel prices.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now, however, ongoing supply-chain constraints related to Chinas strict zero-COVID policy and Russias war in Ukraine are expected to continue to raise the prices of food, fuel, and manufactured goods over the short and medium term.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so supply chains. But I thought that was mostly fixed by now, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so supply chains. But I thought that was mostly fixed by now, you know?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Not quite. And beyond that, increasing geopolitical tensions are making higher input costs a kind of, um, fixture now. It's just part of this deglobalizing world.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not quite. And beyond that, increasing geopolitical tensions are making higher input costs a kind of, um, fixture now. It's just part of this deglobalizing world.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: More broadly, heightened geopolitical tensions threaten to make higher input costs a fixture of a deglobalizing world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Deglobalizing? What does that even mean? So, like, the US is just pulling everything back?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Deglobalizing? What does that even mean? So, like, the U S is just pulling everything back?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, a lot of companies are bringing capital back to the US, prioritizing resilience over, um, low production costs. But that actually means more dollars chasing US assets, which, you know, pushes prices up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, a lot of companies are bringing capital back to the U S, prioritizing resilience over, um, low production costs. But that actually means more dollars chasing U S assets, which, you know, pushes prices up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As interest rates rise and supply chains remain vulnerable, US companies are favoring resilience over low production costs, leading to massive capital repatriation. ... In a deglobalizing economy, more investment capital would flow back to the US, leading to a higher volume of dollars chasing US assets and putting more upward pressure on prices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. That's, uh, counterintuitive. So, like, talent too? Is it harder to get skilled workers now?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. That's, uh, counterintuitive. So, like, talent too? Is it harder to get skilled workers now?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Barriers to migration mean it's tougher for US companies to attract global talent, and that drives up labor costs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Barriers to migration mean it's tougher for U S companies to attract global talent, and that drives up labor costs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Barriers to migration would make it harder for US companies to attract top global talent and drive up labor costs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, man. So, what about the whole world trying to fix this? I thought everyone was, like, working together.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, man. So, what about the whole world trying to fix this? I thought everyone was, like, working together.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's the thing, A. There's been a notable absence of, um, monetary-policy coordination globally.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the thing, A. There's been a notable absence of, um, monetary-policy coordination globally.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Finally, the notable absence of monetary-policy coordination particularly among developed economies may exacerbate global price increases.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, really? Like, unlike 2008 when everyone seemed to, you know, team up?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, really? Like, unlike two thousand eight when everyone seemed to, you know, team up?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unlike the coordinated monetary response to the 2008 global financial crisis, policymakers in the worlds major economies seem to believe that every country must fend for itself in the fight against todays inflationary surge.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. This time, policymakers seem to think every country needs to fend for itself against this inflationary surge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. This time, policymakers seem to think every country needs to fend for itself against this inflationary surge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unlike the coordinated monetary response to the 2008 global financial crisis, policymakers in the worlds major economies seem to believe that every country must fend for itself in the fight against todays inflationary surge.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Even the Fed? Didn't they, uh, try to coordinate?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even the Fed? Didn't they, uh, try to coordinate?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Internal documents from the Fed actually reveal a debate on it, but it was, um, ultimately dismissed due to political disagreements.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Internal documents from the Fed actually reveal a debate on it, but it was, um, ultimately dismissed due to political disagreements.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, like, the sanctions against Russia, did those even help?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, like, the sanctions against Russia, did those even help?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Arguably, they've actually worsened inflationary pressures by increasing supply-chain interruptions and, uh, spiking fuel prices.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Arguably, they've actually worsened inflationary pressures by increasing supply-chain interruptions and, uh, spiking fuel prices.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On the contrary, the one recent coordinated policy action G7 countries undertook sanctions against Russia has arguably worsened inflationary pressures, by increasing supply-chain interruptions and spurring a spike in fuel prices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, when the US Fed raises rates, that affects other countries, too?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, when the U S Fed raises rates, that affects other countries, too?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, big time. It makes the dollar really strong, which means countries with weaker currencies face higher import-led inflation. It's, um, basically exporting inflation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, big time. It makes the dollar really strong, which means countries with weaker currencies face higher import-led inflation. It's, um, basically exporting inflation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When major central banks hike interest rates, they export inflation to smaller countries. Aggressive monetary tightening in the US has already led the dollar to rise against the pound, breach parity with the euro, and reach a 20-year high against the yen, propelling higher import-led inflation in countries whose currencies have weakened.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So it's not just, like, us messing up. It's everyone?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's not just, like, us messing up. It's everyone?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. Even tariffs, like those between the US and China, are adding, uh, 4% to consumer goods prices, according to Oxford. Itâ€™s a very complex, interconnected problem.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. Even tariffs, like those between the U S and China, are adding, uh, four percent to consumer goods prices, according to Oxford. It's a very complex, interconnected problem.
